title: Utrecht Housing
text:
The dataset contains the following columns








variable
description




id
Unique ID


zip_code4
Zip Code 4 digits


zip_code6
Zip Code 6 symbols


zip_code6_id
Zip Code 6 symbols ID


house_type
House Type: Apartment or House


lot_area
Lot Aream, sqm


house_area
House Area, sqm


garden_size
Garden Size, sqm


rooms
Number of Rooms


bathrooms
Number of Bathrooms


x_coor
X Coordinate


y_coor
Y Coordinate


build_year
Build Year


retail_value
Retail Value, kâ‚¬


asking_price
Asking Price, kâ‚¬


energy_label
Energy Label


energy_eff
Energy Efficiency


valuation_date
Valuation Date


street
Street Name


subdistrict
Subdistrict Name


district
District Name


city
City


dist_from_train
Distance from train, km

title: Getting started

Common commands:
pwd          # print working directory
ls           # list files
cd Pictures  # change to Pictures directory
cd ..        # go up one level

title: Getting started
text:
Common commands:
pwd          # print working directory
ls           # list files
cd Pictures  # change to Pictures directory
cd ..        # go up one level

title: Getting started
text:
Installing and using uv
Mac / Linux:
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh
Windows (PowerShell):
powershell -ExecutionPolicy ByPass -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex"
After uv is installed you can check that it is discoverable on your system
uv --version
More info: uv documentation

title: Getting started
text:
Python & Project Setup
Install the latest Python:
uv python install
Create a new project (replace the name if you like):
uv init data-literacy-project
cd data-literacy-project
Install course libraries:
uv add gapminder plotnine polars pyarrow great_tables
uv add --dev setuptools jupyter ipykernel pyyaml nbformat nbclient jupyterlab-quarto
uv creates a pyproject.toml with dependencies and a local .venv for the environment. To restore everything later:
uv sync

title: Getting started
text:
Jupyter
Launch Jupyter
uv run jupyter lab
Here are some shortcuts which can be used in Command mode.



Shortcut
Meaning




Enter
Enter the edit mode


Esc
Exit the edit mode and return to command mode


y
Change cell to code


m
Change cell to markdown (text)


a
Insert cell above


b
Insert cell below


d d
Delete current cell


Ctrl+Enter
Run current cell

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text: The objective of the tutorial is to give student a chance to practice the data wrangling and great tables applying the skills learned through the video lessons on a new dataset.

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text:
Preparation






Note



Before you begin your peer-programming session, please, start the new Jupyter notebook environment in your terminal using the command you learned in Module 1 of the course.
uv run jupyter lab
Create a new notebook and add a text cell atop your document for this practical session. Add a header # Data Visualization and wrangling. Then add a code cell and place the following code there.

import polars as pl
import polars.selectors as cs
from plotnine import *
from great_tables import GT

Then import the datasets for this practical. Add another code cell below (using the key â€˜Bâ€™) and paste the following code. This will import two datasets we will be using in the session: Utrecht and Kingâ€™s County.

ut = pl.read_csv("https://rrr.is/data24utrecht", try_parse_dates=True)
kc = pl.read_csv('https://rrr.is/data24kingscounty', try_parse_dates=True)

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text:
Challenge 1






Challenge



How old is the newest house (woonhuis) with energy class B?

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text:
Challenge 2






Challenge



What are top-3 districts with the largest number of properties in energy class B or better? Do any of these districs have missing values in the energy_label column?
ðŸ’¡ The logical OR operator in Python is denoted by |

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text:
Challenge 3






Challenge



Create a great tables summary showing the proportion of energy-efficient homes (those with an energy label of A or better) for each decade from the 20th and 21st century.
ðŸ’¡ You can group houses by decade by flooring the build year to the start of the decade using integer division //

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text:
Challenge 4






Challenge



Create a great table showing the minimum and maximum retail value per square meter by city and district, as well as the number of houses in each district. Arrange the table by the price range from lowest to highest. Which district has the most expensive housing?
ðŸ’¡ You can count number of records per group with pl.len()

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text:
Challenge 5






Challenge



Use selectors and multi-column expressions for this challenge. Create a great table showing average values (mean()) for all numeric columns and the number of unique values (n_unique()) for all string columns, by district, for all columns except for IDs, zip codes, geographic coordinates and build year. Arrange your table from the priciest to the cheapest district.
ðŸ’¡ This challenge will be easier if you assign prefixes to the aggregated column names. For example you can give numeric columns the prefix avg_ and the string columns the prefix num_. The proportion could be prefixed with prop_. Show proportions as percent in your table.
ðŸ’¡ You can add prefix to a set of columns using .name.prefix('zzz_')

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text:
Challenge 6






Challenge



Make a great table containing Seattle properties that were sold multiple times. For each property ID, show the date of the sale and the price it was sold at.
ðŸ’¡ You will need to remember how to use .over() to complete this challenge.

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text:
Challenge 7






Challenge



Make a great table showing how much profit was made from property flipping (buying and reselling homes) in the top five districts.
ðŸ’¡ You can create a lagged version of a column - e.g.Â to compare consecutive sales of the same property - using .shift(-1).

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text:
Challenge 8






Challenge



Correct the renovation year, to show the year when the most recent renovation happened, or in the absence of it, make it show the construction year.
ðŸ’¡ You can use a conditional expression in Polars such as: pl.when(condition).then(value_if_true).otherwise(value_if_false).

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text:
Challenge 9






Challenge



Visualize the distribution of the property age at the time of sale. Which district is likely to have been developed most recently?
ðŸ’¡ The year of sale can be extracted with pl.col('date').dt.year()

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text:
Challenge 10






Challenge



Explore whether houses in the Highline district that were recently renovated tend to have a higher price per square foot. How does this relationship change after you remove outliers?

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text: Challenge 11

title: Practical 3: Data Wrangling + great tables
text: Challenge 12

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
This is the tutorial for the first practical on Data Visualization with Plotnine
The objective of the tutorial is to give student a chance to practice the data visualization applying the skills learned through the video lessons on a new dataset.

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 1






Challenge



Reproduce this plot.

(
ggplot(ut)+
geom_point(mapping=aes(x='house_area', y='retail_value', color='house_type')) +
labs(x='House Area, sqm', y='Retail Price, kâ‚¬', color='House type')
)

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 2






Challenge



Plot the (asked) price of the house against the number of rooms. Use color to indicate number of bathrooms in each house.



(
ggplot(ut)+
geom_jitter(mapping=aes(x='rooms', y='asking_price', color='factor(bathrooms)')) +
labs(x='Number of rooms', y='Asking Price', color='Bathrooms')
)

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 3






Challenge



How did the energy class of houses evolve for those built during the 20th and 21st century?
What is the build year of the newest house (woonhuis) with energy class B?
ðŸ’¡ You can limit the plot to the years between x1 and x2 using scale_x_continuous(limits=[x1, x2])



(
ggplot(ut)+
geom_jitter(mapping=aes(x='build_year', y='energy_label', color='house_type')) +
scale_x_continuous(limits=[1900, 2025])+
labs(x='Year Built', y='Energy Class', color='House type')
)

/home/dm0737pe/Projects/DATA24/.venv/lib/python3.13/site-packages/plotnine/layer.py:374: PlotnineWarning: geom_jitter : Removed 8 rows containing missing values.










(
ggplot(ut)+
geom_jitter(mapping=aes(x='build_year', y='energy_label', color='house_type')) +
scale_x_continuous(limits=[1998, 2025])+
labs(x='Year Built', y='Energy Class', color='House type')
)

/home/dm0737pe/Projects/DATA24/.venv/lib/python3.13/site-packages/plotnine/layer.py:374: PlotnineWarning: geom_jitter : Removed 81 rows containing missing values.

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 4






Challenge



Reproduce this plot.
ðŸ’¡ If you want to match the color palette as well, itâ€™s qualitative brewer scale number 2
ðŸ’¡ You can add multi-line strings in Python using triple quotes like this """long string which may span multiple lines"""

(
ggplot(ut)+
geom_point(mapping=aes(x='house_area', y='retail_value', color='house_type'))+
geom_smooth(mapping=aes(x='house_area', y='retail_value'),method='lm')+
labs(title='Scatterplot of house area and retail value',
subtitle='Color indicates the type of property',
x='House Area, sqm', y='Retail Price, kâ‚¬', color='House type',
caption="""A linear regression approximates the positive relation between
the variables (with error bands shown in gray)""")+
scale_color_brewer('qual', 2)+
theme_bw()
)

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 5






Challenge



Plot the retail values of houses by district. Which district has the highest median prices, and which has the lowest? Use coord_flip() if the district names are hard to read.



(
ggplot(ut, aes(y='retail_value', x='reorder(district, retail_value)'))+
geom_boxplot()+
coord_flip()+
labs(x="", y="Retail value, kEUR")
)

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 6






Challenge



Plot the distribution of retail values for the two house types. Which of the two appears more symmetrical?



# this could be two separate plots, then after_stat() would not be required
(
ggplot(ut,aes(x='retail_value'))+
geom_histogram(aes(fill='house_type', y=after_stat("density")),bins=15,alpha=0.3)+
geom_density(mapping=aes(color='house_type'))+
facet_wrap('house_type', ncol=1)+
labs(x="Retail value, kEUR")
)

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 7






Challenge



Plot house prices against house size for each district in small multiples. Add a blue linear regression line to each subplot. Which district shows the steepest slope, and which the shallowest?



(
ggplot(ut, aes(y='retail_value', x='house_area'))+
geom_point()+
geom_smooth(method="lm", color="blue")+
labs(y="Retail value, kEUR", x="House Area")+
facet_wrap('district')
)

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 8






Challenge



What are the approximate coordinates of the train station? In which district do you think it is located? And what might be its zip code? (You can Google to check your guess.)



(
ggplot(ut, aes(x='x_coor', y='y_coor', color='dist_from_train'))+
geom_point()
)









(
ggplot(ut, aes(x='x_coor', y='y_coor', color='dist_from_train'))+
geom_point()+
facet_wrap('district')
)









(
ggplot(ut, aes(x='factor(zip_code4)', y='dist_from_train'))+
geom_jitter()+
coord_flip()+
facet_wrap('district', scales='free_y')+
scale_y_log10()

)

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 9






Challenge



Plot house prices against living area, coloring the points by property grade.



(
ggplot(kc, aes(y='price', x='sqft_living', color='grade'))+
geom_point(alpha=0.3)
)

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 10






Challenge



Do newer houses tend to cost more? Do higher-grade houses cost more? Are newer houses generally higher grade?
ðŸ’¡ Use a log scale for house prices to reduce overplotting.



(
ggplot(kc, aes(y='price', x='yr_built', color='grade'))+
geom_point(alpha=0.3)+
scale_y_log10()
)

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 11






Challenge



Visualize the distribution of price per square foot of living area for each housing condition. Would you say that newer houses tend to be in better condition?



(
ggplot(kc, aes(y='price/sqft_living', x='factor(condition)'))+
geom_jitter(aes(color='yr_built'),alpha=0.3)+
geom_boxplot()
)

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 12






Challenge



Visualize the distribution of price per square foot of living area for water-facing and non-water-facing properties. Which distribution appears more symmetrical?



(
ggplot(kc, aes(x='price/sqft_living', color= 'factor(waterfront)', fill='factor(waterfront)'))+
geom_density(alpha=0.3)
)

title: Practical 5: Producing reports with Quarto
text:
This is the tutorial for the first practical on Data Visualization with Plotnine

1 + 1

2




Code
import polars as pl
from plotnine import *
from gapminder import gapminder

The pkg_resources package is slated for removal as early as 2025-11-30. Refrain from using this package or pin to Setuptools<81.

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text: The objective of the tutorial is to give student a chance to practice the data visualization and data wrangling applying the skills learned through the video lessons on a new dataset.

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Preparation






Note



Before you begin your peer-programming session, please, start the new Jupyter notebook environment in your terminal using the command you learned in Module 1 of the course.
uv run jupyter lab
Create a new notebook and add a text cell atop your document for this practical session. Add a header # Data Visualization and wrangling. Then add a code cell and place the following code there.

import polars as pl
import polars.selectors as cs
from plotnine import *

Then import the datasets for this practical. Add another code cell below (using the key â€˜Bâ€™) and paste the following code. This will import two datasets we will be using in the session: Utrecht and Kingâ€™s County.

ut = pl.read_csv("https://rrr.is/data24utrecht", try_parse_dates=True)
kc = pl.read_csv('https://rrr.is/data24kingscounty', try_parse_dates=True)

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 1






Challenge



What is the average garden size for the houses in the Utrecht dataset? What is the median distance from the train station?

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 2






Challenge



Plot house area against lot area for the woonhuis properties and add a linear trend line. Which points stand out as outliers from the overall pattern? Roughly what lot area would you expect for a 200 sqm house based on this line?
ðŸ’¡ You can pass the data to plotnine using the .pipe() method.

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 3






Challenge



Do the outliers you identified in the previous plot also stand out in the relationship between house area and asking price? Do these outliers correspond to newer or older houses? Are they located close to one another? What are their 4-digit zip codes?

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 4






Challenge



Create a small dataset that includes only houses from the zip codes identified in the previous challenge. Show the street name, house size, lot area, build year, energy class, and asking price. How many houses are in your dataset? Arrange the observations by the year the houses were built. On which street is the oldest of these houses located?

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 5






Challenge



Which 4-digit zip code includes the largest number of streets?
Within that zip code, what is the street name of the house closest to the train station?
ðŸ’¡ You can count unique values using n_unique() and find the minimum value with min()

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 6






Challenge



Plot a line showing the average house size per decade in the 20th century. How many peaks in the house sizes can you identify?
ðŸ’¡ The whole-number division in Python is written as //

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 7






Challenge



Calculate the average square meter price per valuation week based on the retail value and plot it. Do you see any trend in real estate prices over time?
ðŸ’¡ Measure per square meter price as retail value divided by house area
ðŸ’¡ You can extract the ISO week number from the date using the .dt.week() method

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 8






Challenge



Which street has the highest number of energy-efficient houses? What proportion of houses on that street are energy efficient? When was the oldest of these houses built?
ðŸ’¡ You can calculate the proportion using .over() clause

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 9






Challenge



Define the asking price premium as the percentage difference between the asking price and the retail value. Which house has the highest asking price premium in the dataset? Compare this house to the others on the same street â€” is it also the most expensive on a per-square-meter basis?
Plot the distribution of asking price per square meter. What do the top three most expensive properties in Utrecht (per square meter) have in common?
ðŸ’¡ You can see the house on Google Street View if you search Google Maps using x_coor, y_coor.

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 10






Challenge



Plot the number of houses sold in each district.
ðŸ’¡ Use a bar chart to visualize the counts and flip the coordinates to make the labels easier to read. Research the difference between a bar chart and a column plot in Plotnine. Investigate how to use the reorder() function in Plotnine and see if you can improve your plot with it.

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 11






Challenge



How many houses changed owners more than once? What is the maximum number of times a house was sold? Where is this house located? How much profit was made by flipping it?

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 12






Challenge



Plot the average monthly house prices. Do you see signs of house-price inflation? Does your conclusion hold for every district?
ðŸ’¡ ou can round dates to the start of each month using dt.month_start().

title: Kings County Housing
text:
The dataset contains the following columns








variable
description




id
Unique ID for each home sold


date
Date of the home sale


price
Price of each home sold


bedrooms
Number of bedrooms


bathrooms
Number of bathrooms


sqft_living
Square footage of the apartments interior living space


sqft_lot
Square footage of the land space


floors
Number of floors


waterfront
A dummy variable for whether the apartment was overlooking the waterfront or not


view
An index from 0 to 4 of how good the view of the property was


condition
An index from 1 to 5 on the condition of the apartment


grade
An index from 1 to 13 where 1-3 falls short of building construction and design, 7 has an average level of construction and design and 11-13 have a high quality level of construction and design


sqft_above
Square footage of the interior housing space above ground level


sqft_basement
Square footage of the interior housing space below ground level


yr_built
Year the house was initially built


yr_renovated
Year of the houseâ€™s last renovation and, if not renovated, the year built


zipcode
Zipcode the house belongs to


lat
Latitude


long
Longitude


sqft_living15
Average square footage of the apartments interior living space for the nearest 15 neighbors


sqft_lot15
Average square footage of the land space for the nearest 15 neighbors


district
School district name
